Dragons are fine the way they are? Do you follow the state of the game at all, or do you just like to make uninformed proclamations about it? At high levels of play, especially in professional play, it's been abundantly clear for many months that dragon is essentially worthless. The first dragon is nice, dragons 2-4 are irrelevant, and dragon #5 is the only reason to even be killing dragons after the first buff - but games very very rarely reach that point.

Why is this a problem? If the objective is worthless, it makes for less interesting games. Dragon is almost never contested in professional play, it's simply not worth fighting over, which means a lot of time is just spent in lane AFK pushing while waiting for an objective that actually matters to appear on the map (Baron). It completely changes the pacing of the game for the worse when there's not a meaningful early objective for teams to jockey for control of.

When was the last time you watch professional play? 2012? Dragon is anything but highly defended, in fact it's basically the opposite of defended. If one team goes for dragon in the LCK you'll always see the other team immediately move not to defend dragon but instead to take Rift Herald in exchange. Rift Herald is also similarly useless, and they just trade low value objective for low value objective.

Dragons 2-4 don't really help with split pushing as much as you think. Dragon 2 only saves you a couple of AAs on a tower, which is fine but not going to compel people to take an objective. Dragon 4 is completely useless, a single spell rotation from any splitpushing or waveclearing champion that late in the game is going to kill minions with or without 15% extra. Dragon 3 is the most useful of the mid dragons, but the bonus is still small enough that teams don't put any kind of priority on it.
All this. I always felt like Dragon 2 and 4 should be switched, which would just make 4 that much less meaningful but still the minion damage would be nice earlier.

They were that way but it was switched to avoid top laners from getting GOOD split pushing power for doing absolutely nothing. Also getting the minion damage one made a lot or wave clear mid laners clear waves earlier thus making longer games due to it being harder to seige against them earlier.

It's the 6% Deal... you only take Dragon EARLY if you are going for a 5 Dragon Win Condition.

The resources to take Dragon 1 early, while exposing yourself to losing an Early Turret for it, are to great and sets you behind in both Gold and Level.

So you have to have either a really good Early Team to still be stronger despite the Level/Gold disadvantage of taking Dragon (funny how that is a Disadvantage)... OR playing for the Super Late Game (5th Dragon and the point where 6% AD/AP Bonus matters).

So I agree an Early Dragon is never contested... but Dragon is certainly contested once it gets to the point of being worth the expense to take it.

I'd actually like to know why the buffs aren't fine, and I'm sure the person you told to shut up would love to hear it too.

Dragon Buff 4 is completely irrelevant.

By the time you get to buff 4 it's at least 22 minutes, if not 30+.

You don't need 15% damage to minions at that point. It doesn't help you at all - any damage oriented champion can insta-kill each minion before the buff. Any non-damage oriented champion doesn't benefit from a damage buff. In general, none of the buffs help non-damage oriented champions (except dragons 3 and 5, and only a little for the MS). 

So buff 4 is a huge waste. The only reason to get dragon 4 was to threaten for dragon 5. Games often don't last that long though, so instead of taking dragon 4 you're better off taking a turret and ending the game before dragon 5 spawns. 

The change to dragon 4 makes real sense. 30% damage reduction is too much, but 15% sounds good. I don't think it should triple on dragon 5, perhaps only double (I'm sure they can pull that off). Damage reduction from turrets is useful late game as good waveclear teams can just stall under turret. It makes dragon 4 not quite as strong as Baron but still a reasonable option to crack a stall comp. If you recognize the enemy team has good waveclear, perhaps you'll prioritize dragons more.

Dragon 2 change is fine, I don't think dragon 4 is the right way to implement a change to pushing power. Problem is, by the time a team has 4 dragons (25 minutes at earliest, and that's incredibly unlikely) tanks already can dive turrets fairly easily, and even some fighters don't have much problems diving if they are ahead. Even if it's 15% (which would make it even more useless, but would prevent dragon 5 from being literally a "dive every turret in a row" win condition), that's not really an issue a lot of champions would have pushing turrets. 

The things that make it hard to close out a game are lack of available vision options (now that green wards can't be bought, and SS nerfs), as well as heavy waveclear. If either of those things were chipped down by dragon buffs, then it might be good. For example, trinket CD reduction of 30% for the vision, or maybe if you like making turrets much weaker from dragon instead, have minions (all?/near champions?) also gain the damage reduction from turrets. This would help separate dragon 4 from baron by making minions better at taking turrets, but also would provide an enviroment where {{champion:34}} {{champion:112}}  can't just clear every wave in a 4v4 siege with no problems (sidelane minions alone would threaten turrets left undefended). If this still doesn't feel good enough, have minions take reduced damage from enemy minions as well (I don't remember if this has been introduced yet with the team level advantage/lane turret advantage).

tl;dr Turret diving is already easy 30+ minutes into the game, so this buff still doesn't deal with the difficulty of closing out a game.
